titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Joannes de Carro Letter, 1805, 1841
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, January 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: On July 24, 1805, Frederic North, Governor of Ceylon, responded to de Carro's inquiries and noted Jonville, Barnard, and Thomas Christie, physician who introduced vaccination into Ceylon. The manuscript contains a signed, autograph note by Carro dated 1841 in which he stated that Christie was his correspondent about vaccination in Ceylon.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Joannes de Carro letter, 1805, 1841, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, January 2018.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Austrian physician and author of a number of works about the mineral springs at Carlsbad, vaccination, and other subjects.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: On July 24, 1805, Frederic North, Governor of Ceylon, responded to de Carro's inquiries and noted Jonville, Barnard, and Thomas Christie, physician who introduced vaccination into Ceylon. The manuscript contains a signed, autograph note by Carro dated 1841 in which he stated that Christie was his correspondent about vaccination in Ceylon.
